citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During the inspection, the applicant provided an animal care document. The applicant stated that the document was
reviewed by the veterinarian. The applicant also stated that the veterinarian had approved their care for all the animals.
There was no indication that the veterinarian had reviewed and approved the care plan. A follow-up phone call with the
veterinarian confirmed that the care plan had not been reviewed and approved by the veterinarian.
Without veterinary guidance, animals may not receive optimal care. Applicant shall develop and maintain a care plan that
has been reviewed and approved by the veterinarian.

The enclosure for one of the singing dogs was pulled away from the wall during the inspection to inspect all sides of the
enclosure. The enclosure had feces and fur accumulated along the entire back bottom ledge. The accumulated fur
covered the entire length of the edge and hung down the side below the enclosure. There was also dust and fur along
the top of the enclosure and on the back of the wooden bench on top of the enclosure. Another singing dog enclosure
had similar fur underneath and along the back edge of the enclosure.
Inspecting the back side of the enclosure housing two ferrets revealed feces accumulated along the back edges of the
pen. The feces was a pile that was approximately 4 inches x 2 inches and 1 inch deep in the corner of the enclosure. A
second corner of the enclosure had a pile of accumulated feces that was approximately 5 inches x 2 inches and 1/2 inch
deep.
The enclosure housing two fennec foxes and one pale fox had litter pans that had smeared feces on the sides. The
enclosure also had resting shelves that had a layer of dust on them.
Failure to adequately clean and sanitize animal enclosures increases the risk of disease. All enclosures should be
cleaned and sanitized frequently and thoroughly to eliminate the accumulation of fur and feces.

The regulated animals, ie: 7 red foxes; 4 singing dogs; 2 fennec foxes; 1 pale fox; and 2 ferrets that are used in exhibition,
are all housed in rooms of the applicant's primary residence. The house is approximately 1100 sq feet. Also housed are
personal pets (11 cats, 3 dogs, 4 rabbits, two enclosures housing numerous rats). The rooms are overcrowded with
stored items such as donated food, bedding, personal items and other supplies. There are lidded bins stacked next to
and on top of the animal enclosures and where ever there is space in the home. There was dust and spilled food along
the tops of the bins and on the floor beside the bins along the wall. There is minimal clearance to work with and access
the animals, clean the enclosures as well as clean the walls and areas around the enclosures. The lack of access for
proper cleaning allows buildup of fur, dust and spoiled food under and behind the enclosures. The lack of access
prevents proper husbandry and puts the animals at risk of disease. Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to
protect the animals from injury and to facilitate prescribed husbandry practices.
This is a 3rd Re-License Inspection for a Class C license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
The applicant is not currently in compliance with the AWA as documented above. You may appeal this finding in writing by
March 23, 2023.
Appeals should be addressed to:
Dr. Elizabeth Goldentyer
APHIS Animal Care(AC)
U.S. Department of Agriculture
4700 River Road | 6D-03F
Riverdale, MD 20787
Or emailed to:
animalcareappeals@usda.gov
Your existing license is expired and a new license will not be issued. Conducting regulated activities without a valid USDA
license is a violation of the Animal Welfare Act.
A new application may be submitted for consideration after September 9, 2023.
Additional Inspectors:
REBECCA NANNEY, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICEREnd Section
